The effects of solvents on lignin depolymerization are crucial for optimizing biomass valorization strategies. This study examines how various solvents influence oxidative lignin depolymerization under different reaction conditions. The findings highlight the significant role of solvents in lignin degradation, affecting conversion rates through factors like solvating capacity, polarity, and hydrogen bonding interactions. Notably, alcoholic solvents such as methanol exhibit strong catalytic effects due to their high polarity and hydrogen-donating capabilities. Under conditions with phosphomolybdic acid as the catalyst, methanol as the solvent, a temperature of 120 °C, a reaction time of 120 min, 1 MPa oxygen pressure, and a catalyst-to-lignin ratio of 1:1, the oxidative depolymerization of lignin yielded aromatic compounds with a production rate of 12.95 wt%. To further assess solvent effects, simulation models were developed, indicating that polarity has the most substantial impact, followed by hydrogen-bond donating and accepting properties. Particularly, a polarity parameter that comprehensively considers hydrogen bonding potential shows promise in predicting the yield of oily products during oxidative lignin depolymerization. These insights provide a foundation for selecting effective solvents to enhance lignin transformation, contributing to the development of sustainable biorefinery processes. Biomass is increasingly recognized as a renewable resource with the potential to replace fossil fuels due to its abundance and lower environmental impact [3–5]. Among biomass resources, lignocellulosic biomass—which includes cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin—stands out. As the second most abundant component after cellulose, lignin holds promise as a sustainable substitute for fossil resources [6,7]. However, lignin is often reduced to low-value byproducts or inefficiently burned as fuel, wasting its potential and causing environmental harm [8,9]. Its complex, three-dimensional structure of polymerized phenylpropane units also limits efficient conversion [10–12]. Effective lignin conversion into high-value chemicals, therefore, is essential to addressing energy challenges [13]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) possess tunable Brønsted acidity and redox properties, and their notable thermal stability, adaptable structures, as well as exceptional catalytic performance, have garnered considerable attention from scholars worldwide, They serve as ideal catalysts for the oxidative degradation of biomass [14–16]. For instance, Li et al. [17] selected bifunctional acidic/redox-active POMs, namely H3PW, H3PMo, and H5PMoV2, as the catalysts. The catalytic performance of H3PMo is optimal, achieving a cellulose conversion rate of 83 % and a yield of 52 % for glucaric acid (GA). The author further synthesized the [MIMPS]H2PMo catalyst, which exhibited an activity of 100 % and a selectivity of 75 % when subjected to microwave irradiation at 190 °C for a duration of 2 min. This research sheds light on the understanding of the acidic/redox properties of POMs in the conversion of cellulosic biomass, offering insights that can aid in the design and synthesis of POM-based catalysts. Hombach et al. [18] developed an acid catalyst by immobilizing phosphotungstic acid on activated carbon. Under the action of this catalyst, hemicellulose xylan was selectively hydrolyzed into the platform compound xylose, achieving a yield of 74 %. The catalyst is easy to recover and demonstrates good reusability, with a consistent leaching amount of only 3–4 % after 20 cycles of hemicellulose xylan hydrolysis. Wei et al. [19] synthesized an Anderson-type POM catalyst, [CTAC][CoMo], and used it to oxidatively degrade larch lignin. The monomer yield of phenolic compounds was 12.43 wt%. Further studies using lignin dimer model compounds revealed that the catalyst effectively cleaved the β-O-4 CC bond. The catalyst remained stable over five cycles, demonstrating the potential of Anderson-type POM catalysts in promoting sustainable biomass conversion to value-added chemicals. Xin et al. [20] successfully constructed a POMs-ionic liquid (POMs-IL) catalyst by reacting H5PMo10V2O40 (HPMoV) with 1-methyl-3-(4-sulfobutyl)−1H-imidazolium. This POM-IL catalyst efficiently and selectively converted various β-O-4 lignin models into aromatic acids and phenolic compounds in a mild homogeneous environment. The catalyst could be easily recovered by adding ethyl acetate to the reaction mixture and maintained high stability through five consecutive cycles. Mechanistic studies revealed the main catalytic pathways. Li et al. [21] employed POMs as catalysts for oxidative catalytic fractionation (OCF) technology. In a methanol-water mixed solvent and oxygen environment, they directly oxidized lignocellulosic lignin from pine into aromatic compounds, with major products including vanillin and methyl vanillate, achieving a yield of 22.5 %. This study offers a new perspective on the high-selectivity oxidative fractionation and depolymerization of lignin and contributes to the conversion of lignocellulose into high-value compounds. In summary, POMs exhibit high catalytic activity in biomass degradation, with minimal environmental impact during preparation and use. They align with the principles of green chemistry and show significant advantages in biomass conversion processes. Oxidative depolymerization is widely used for lignin conversion and has strong potential for producing aromatic compounds under mild conditions [22–24]. Catalytic oxidative depolymerization enables the formation of diverse functionalized aromatic products, where catalytic strategy selection is crucial for optimizing monomer yields. For instance, Lancefield et al. [25] developed a two-step catalytic oxidative hydrolysis process using a DDQ/tBuONO and O₂ system to selectively convert benzyl alcohols in lignin to carbonyl groups, thereby lowering the CO bond energy. This approach produced a simplified mixture of products, which could be easily purified to yield pure compounds. On another front, Springer et al. [26] conducted conversion of lignin and β-O-4 model compounds in organic solvents by activating hydrogen peroxide with manganese catalysts. They observed the formation of 5–5 and 4-O-5 linkages during the oxidation process, resulting in a significant increase in the molecular weight of the model compounds upon lignin transformation. This phenomenon was attributed to the generation of phenoxyl radicals, leading to concurrent repolymerization reactions alongside oxidative process. Furthermore, different types of catalysts also exert influence on lignin conversion. Ouyang et al. [27], using 1:1(v/v) methanol/H2O as the reaction solvent, found that the yield of monophenol compounds reached 17.92 wt%, and the appropriate ratio of methanol to H2O effectively maintained the alkalinity of the reaction medium and the solubility of lignin. Methanol could promote the cleavage of aryl ether bonds and effectively inhibit the repolymerization of polymerized lignin fragments. Das et al. [28] employed niobium oxide as a catalyst for the partial oxidation of lignin. This research revealed that the choice of oxidizing agent significantly impacted the generation of vanillin, while exerting a minor influence on the production of acetyl vanillin. Moreover, Deng et al. [29] synthesized LaCo1−xCuxO3 composite metal oxides via the sol-gel method as catalysts for lignin depolymerization to produce aromatic aldehydes. Their study showed that copper doping in LaCoO₃ created anionic vacancies, enhancing surface oxygen adsorption capacity. In summary, selecting suitable catalytic oxidative depolymerization strategy is vital for maximizing monomer yields in lignin conversion. The efficacy of oxidative transformation as a method underscores the need for continued innovation in catalyst design and optimization to improve conversion efficiency and selectivity. The role of solvent in lignin depolymerization is crucial, as it directly influences the efficiency and selectivity of the process. The choice of solvent can enhance lignin dissolution, promote interactions between catalysts and lignin, and stabilize intermediates during reactions [30]. Various studies have demonstrated the impact of solvent systems on lignin depolymerization outcomes. For example, McVeigh et al. [31] observed that methanol increased the solubility of lignin, improving the interaction with a Pt/Al₂O₃ catalyst, and achieving 43.5 % alkylphenol yield. Similarly, Voitl et al. [32] highlighted the role of methanol in preventing lignin condensation by competing with intermediate carbon ions, leading to higher yields of vanillin and methyl vanillate. Supercritical ethanol, as shown by Huang et al. [33], acted as both a hydrogen donor and stabilizer, inhibiting re-aggregation and improving monomer yields. Wu et al. [34] demonstrated that anethanol/dioxane/f-ormic acid mixed solvent facilitated acid-depolymerization and increased the yield of alkylated phenolic products through a synergistic solvent effect. The influence of pH and cation concentration in an ethanol/H₂O system was also noted by Chaudhary et al. [35], where a pH of 9.2 was optimal for achieving high monomer yields. In contrast, Long et al. [36] found that although tetrahydrofuran (THF) increased lignin solubility and improved catalytic performance, re-aggregation within catalyst pores diminished the overall efficiency. For other solvent system, Adler et al. [37] achieved close to 100 % yield of guaiacyl phenol by catalyzing the degradation of a lignin model compound in a H2O/dioxane solution using 0.2 M HCl. The cleavage of aryl ether bonds was the main source of phenylpropane-like products. These findings emphasize the importance of selecting the right solvent system to optimize lignin conversion. Considering the intricate interplay between solvent properties and lignin depolymerization, further studies are necessary to gain a clearer understanding of how specific solvent characteristics affect the yield and selectivity of lignin-derived products. Despite the valuable insights provided by various studies on lignin depolymerization in specific solvents, there remains a gap in the comprehensive comparison of solvent effects, particularly in terms of their individual characteristics such as solubility, polarity, and hydrogen bonding. To address this, the current study aims to systematically investigate how these solvent properties impact monomer yield and depolymerization efficiency. Using cellulose enzyme lignin (CEL) as the substrate, we explored its depolymerization in a range of organic solvents under POMs catalysis. This research will provide a deeper understanding of how solvents influence transformation mechanisms, establishing a theoretical foundation for optimizing reaction conditions. Ultimately, our findings will contribute to advancing lignin oxidative depolymerization processes, with implications for industrial-scale lignin valorization. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Lignin isolation from cellulosic ethanol biorefinery residue The cellulose ethanol lignin residue (provided by Shandong Longli Ethanol Technology Co., Ltd., China) was ground to a powder below 100 mesh, and 5.0 g of the sample was weighed and placed into a three-necked flask. Subsequently, Add 40 ml of 3 % NaOH aqueous solution. Stir the mixture continuously for 1 h in a H2O bath at around 65 °C, followed by a 30 min incubation period. The resulting mixture was then vacuum filtered, and its pH was adjusted to 3.2 using a 2 % H2SO4 solution. Keep the mixture in a H2O bath at 70 °C for 30 min, followed by a 24 h settling period. The supernatant was separated through centrifugation, and after three rounds of H2O washing and subsequent centrifugation at 60 °C, the sample was dried. The obtained sample was dissolved in a solution of 1,4-dioxane, followed by precipitation using ethyl ether. The resulting precipitate was then separated through centrifugation and dried, yielding a relatively high-purity CEL product. 2.2 Preparation of POMs catalysts Preparation of H3PW12O40: Dissolve 10 g of Na2WO4·2H2O in 10 mL of H2O and heated until the solution is clarified. Then, add 1 mL 85 % phosphoric acid, then gradually add 8 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid. After cooling, the crystalline product was obtained. After 4 h, the product was filtered under reduced pressure to remove excess solvent. Then dissolve the obtained product in 12 mL of H2O and transfer it into a separating funnel. To the funnel, add 4 mL HCl and 7 mL of C4H10O and shake to release gas. The mixture was allowed to settle, and the gas was released. Transfer the bottom mixture to another separation funnel. Then, add 12 mL of H2O and the mixture was oscillated. Next, add 4 mL of HCl and 3 mL of ether and shake to release gas. The sample was mixed with potassium bromide (KBr) at a 1:100 ratio, prepared into a pellet using the KBr tablet method, and scanned to collect signals in the range of 400 cm⁻¹ to 4000 cm⁻¹. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Analysis of lignin transformation performance in different solvents In this study, we used commonly employed organic solvents for the liquid-phase depolymerization of lignin, and the monomer yield after transformation is shown in Fig. 1 (a). UV–visible spectrophotometry (UV) tests were performed for different solvents, as illustrated in Fig. 1(b). The peak around 280 nm corresponds to the solubility of CEL in the solvent, with a higher peak indicating better lignin solubility [40]. Additionally, to directly assess the solubility of CEL in different solvents, photographs were taken after CEL was dissolved in each solvent at room temperature, as shown in Fig. 1(c). Fig. 1(a) shows that methanol, when used as the solvent, yields the highest monomer production under mild conditions. Both methanol and ethanol significantly outperform other solvents in terms of monomer yield. The product composition analysis reveals that, in methanol, the primary monomeric products of CEL conversion are the methyl esters of 4-hydroxycinnamic acid and ferulic acid, while in ethanol, the main monomeric products are the ethyl esters of para-hydroxycinnamic acid and ferulic acid. This suggests that methanol and ethanol not only act as solvents but also participate in the reaction, enhancing CEL depolymerization. Additionally, the UV characteristic curve indicates that methanol and ethanol exhibit excellent lignin solubility, enabling better dissolution of CEL and thereby promoting the reaction. Lignin dissolution is a critical factor in the depolymerization process, as it facilitates key reaction pathways, including the breaking of chemical bonds, the formation of new active sites, and hydroxyl functionalization, all of which can be enhanced by good solubility [41]. Fig. 1(b) and Fig. 1(c) demonstrate that the high polarity of methanol and ethanol enhances lignin solubility, which significantly promotes the depolymerization reaction. Although acetone, isopropanol, and n-butanol also have moderate polarity, their monomer yields are relatively low, likely due to reaction conditions that may not fully optimize CEL depolymerization. These solvents also leave considerable residues, suggesting that the mild conditions applied may be insufficient for complete depolymerization. In contrast, n-hexane, with limited lignin solubility, tends to produce substantial char, likely due to incomplete reaction. While solvents like tetrahydrofuran, ethyl acetate, and 1,4-dioxane show strong lignin solubility, they yield viscous oil-like products rather than high monomer yields, indicating that factors beyond solubility, such as methanol's function as an active hydrogen donor, could play a critical role in improving depolymerization. These observations are supported by UV data: polar protic solvents, particularly alcohols, demonstrate stronger lignin dissolution abilities compared to nonpolar solvents like n-hexane. The notably low absorption peak for n-hexane around 280 nm further underscores its limited lignin solubility and reduced effectiveness in facilitating depolymerization. 3.2 FT-IR analysis of POMs The infrared spectrum of the H3PMo12O40 catalyst is shown in Fig. 2 , which displays four absorption peaks characteristic of the Keggin structure of POMs. The four characteristic absorption peaks at 1064 cm⁻¹, 964 cm⁻¹, 871 cm⁻¹, and 785 cm⁻¹ correspond to the P-O, Mo-Oter, Mo-Oc-Mo, and Mo-Oe-Mo bonds, respectively. This confirms the successful synthesis of the Keggin-type catalyst H3PMo12O40. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions for depolymerization efficiency Monomer yield of lignin depolymerization is significantly influenced by the reaction temperature. The increase in reaction temperature can speed up the reaction rate, but it may also cause side reactions and condensation[42]. The impact of different temperatures on the formation of aromatic compounds in the CEL depolymerization products is shown in Fig. 3 (a). As the reaction temperature increases from 80 °C to 120 °C, the yield of aromatic compounds gradually increases from 7.18 wt% to a maximum of 12.95 wt%. However, further increasing the temperature cause a decrease in the yield. This is mainly due to the fact that at low temperatures, increasing the temperature helps break the side chain linkages of lignin. However, excessively high temperatures may cause further oxidation of the depolymerized lignin monomers into carbon dioxide and H2O, leading to the transformation rate reduction by damaging the structure of lignin monomers. The effect of reaction time on the yield of aromatic compounds in CEL conversion products follows a trend similar to that observed with temperature variations. As shown in Fig. 3(b), extending the reaction time from 0.5 h to 6 h initially increases the yield of aromatic compounds, which then declines. This trend likely results from condensation reactions occurring among the depolymerized lignin monomers when reaction times are prolonged. Additionally, significant residue was observed in the 4 h and 6 h experiments, suggesting that lignin intermediate products recondense under extended reaction conditions. To maximize the yield of aromatic compounds, therefore, the reaction time should be carefully controlled within an optimal range. Fig. 3(c) presents the effect of various reaction atmospheres on the yield of aromatic compounds from CEL conversion. A sufficient oxygen environment is essential for the oxidative depolymerization of lignin to proceed effectively. Under nitrogen, a monomer yield of only 3.61 wt% was obtained, indicating that limited lignin depolymerization reaction occurred. In contrast, an oxygen-rich atmosphere at optimal concentrations promotes the reaction. As oxygen pressure increased, the monomer yield rose steadily from 5.31 wt% to 12.95 wt%. However, when oxygen pressure exceeded 1.0 MPa, the yield dropped sharply, likely due to excessive oxygen pressure causing over-oxidation of lignin degradation intermediates, which ultimately lowered the final yield. The oxidizing and acidic properties of catalysts significantly impact reaction yield by participating in the depolymerization of lignin [43]. Fig. 3(d) illustrates the distribution of CEL transformation products catalyzed by different catalysts. Among the three catalysts, H5PMo10V2O40, H3PMo12O40, and H3PW12O40, the yields of aromatic compounds are 1.13 wt%, 12.95 wt%, and 1.41 %, respectively. H3PMo12O40 demonstrates higher catalytic activity than H3PW12O40, likely due to the introduction of Mo atoms, which enhances H3PMo12O40’s oxidizing power, facilitating the cleavage of lignin side chains. However, substituting vanadium into H3PMo12O40 to obtain H5PMo10V2O40, although increasing oxidizing strength, significantly decreases catalytic activity. This reduction may be attributed to the excessive oxidizing power, which can cause ring-opening reactions or even over-oxidation of the lignin benzene rings to carbon dioxide and H2O, ultimately lowering the aromatic compound yield. Thus, when using POMs as catalysts for lignin depolymerization, it is essential to balance the catalyst's oxidizing power to maximize product yield. The amount of catalyst plays a critical role in determining monomer yield during lignin depolymerization. As shown in Fig. 3(e), varying the mass ratio of the catalyst to lignin influences the transformation products. As the amount of H3PMo12O40 increases, the yield gradually improves. This suggests that a higher quantity of H3PMo12O40 provides more active sites, facilitating the breakdown of lignin molecules. When the mass ratio of H3PMo12O40 to CEL reaches 1.5:1, the reaction yield stabilizes. However, at a 2:1 ratio, the monomer yield begins to decrease, suggesting that an excess of catalyst may lead to over-oxidation reactions. Thus, the optimal mass ratio of H3PMo12O40 to CEL for maximizing yield appears to be 1:1. 3.4 Characterization of the depolymerized products The average molecular weight of oligomers in the degradation products was determined using gel permeation chromatography (GPC). This analysis helps to understand the effectiveness of the depolymerization process, optimize reaction conditions and catalyst design, and evaluate the quality and application potential of the depolymerized products. The weight-average molecular weight (Mw), number-average molecular weight (Mn), and polydispersity (PD) of the oligomers obtained after optimizing the reaction conditions with CEL and methanol as the solvent are shown in Table 1 . Before reaction, the Mw and Mn of CEL were 12,610 g/mol and 11,013 g/mol, respectively. After reaction, the Mw and Mn significantly decreased to 3608 g/mol and 3598 g/mol, indicating effective depolymerization of CEL under the optimized conditions. Fig. 4 shows the Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra of both the side chain region (δC/δH 45–90/3.0–6.0 ppm) and the aromatic ring region (δC/δH 95–140/6.0–8.5 ppm) before and after conversion. In the side chain region, the NMR signals indicate the primary linkages of CEL, including β-O-4, β−5, and β-β [44]. By comparing spectra before and after reaction, the proportions of these linkages, calculated from the Cα integral of the benzene ring side chain, are 81 % for β-O-4, 16 % for β−5, and 3 % for β-β, with β-O-4 being the most abundant. After methanol conversion, the signals Aα (δC/δH 71–74/4.8–5.3 ppm), Bα (δC/δH 86–88/5.6–5.7 ppm), and Cα (δC/δH 83–85/4.5–4.7 ppm) significantly diminished, indicating that the β-O-4, β−5, and β-β linkages were effectively cleaved in methanol. In the aromatic ring region, the spectrum reveals the three main lignin units: guaiacyl (G), syringyl (S), and p-hydroxyphenyl (H). As shown in Fig. 4(b), CEL contains G, S, and H units. After transformation, signals for S2/6 (δC/δH 103–106/6.7–7.3 ppm) and H2/6 (δC/δH 127–128/6.9–7.3 ppm) disappear, while signals for G2, G5, and G6 are significantly weakened, though some structural components remain. Interestingly, despite the lower initial content of H-type units in CEL, a relatively higher proportion of H-type products is observed after conversion. This may suggest that some S-type and G-type products undergo demethoxylation reactions and are converted to H-type structures during the reaction, highlighting the high reactivity of methanol. 3.5 Mechanistic insights into the solvent effect The solvent effects on lignin depolymerization are evident from the experimental results. Lignin transformation in solvents is influenced by factors such as solubility, polarity, and hydrogen bond acceptor capacity, which can be quantitatively described through various solvent parameters [45,46].These include hydrogen-bond donation (α), hydrogen-bond acceptance (β),polarity/polarizab-ility (π), polarity parameter (ET), donor number (DN), and acceptor number (AN). Table 1 presents the ten solvent parameters used in Fig. 1, along with the corresponding conversion product yields, to analyze the solvent effects. Solvents can be classified into three groups based on their intrinsic characteristics: (1) Polar Protic Solvents (e.g., methanol, ethanol, isopropanol, n-butanol), which can donate or accept hydrogen bonds and exhibit a wide range of polarity parameter (ET) values. (2) Polar Aprotic Solvents (e.g., acetone, dioxane, tetrahydrofuran, ethyl acetate), which lack hydrogen bond donation capacity (α=0 or nearly 0) but can accept hydrogen bonds. (3) Nonpolar Solvents (e.g., n-hexane, dichloromethane), which do not donate electron pairs (DN=0 or nearly 0) and lack Lewis basicity. Notably, n-hexane stands out as it neither donates nor accepts hydrogen bonds (α, β=0) (Table 2 ). From Table 1, significant variations in the yield of oily products from the oxidative depolymerization of CEL under different solvents are evident, primarily due to differences in solubility parameters. When methanol is used as the solvent, the yield of oily products reaches its highest at 53.86 %. Ethanol also shows a relatively high yield at 48.77 %. In contrast, the use of n-hexane as the solvent results in the lowest yield of oily products, at just 15.93 %. These polar protic solvents exhibit superior CEL solubilization capabilities compared to nonpolar solvents, with n-hexane in particular showing poor solubilization. The limited ability of n-hexane to donate or accept hydrogen bonds makes it significantly less effective than the other solvents. To quantitatively evaluate the impact of various solvent parameters on CEL conversion, we establish a correlation between the yields of lignin oily products and the solubility parameters, as shown in Fig. 4. The relationship between the polarity of different solvents (ET) and the yield of oily products from CEL is shown in Fig. 5 (a). The solvent parameter ET captures both specific and nonspecific interactions of the solvent during the reaction process [47]. As illustrated in the graph, the highest yield of oily products reaches 53.86 %. The fit for n-hexane is notably poor, likely due to its lower solubility for both CEL and its depolymerized products. This solubility discrepancy can lead to condensation reactions between CEL and its depolymerized products, resulting in condensation reaction formation. The correlation between the polar solvent parameter ET and the yield of oily products from CEL depolymerization is described by the simulated equation in Eq. (1). The model reveals a strong linear relationship, with an R² value of 0.912. This positive correlation indicates that higher solvent polarity generally promotes the production of lignin-derived oily products. Additionally, ET proves to be a reliable solvent parameter for predicting oily product yields during the oxidative depolymerization of lignin, as confirmed by this model. While the correlation between the polarity parameter ET and the yield of lignin-derived oily products shows promising results, the distinct experimental outcomes observed with n-hexane highlight that polarity alone is not sufficient to fully explain the factors influencing yield. We propose that additional solvent parameters also significantly influence CEL depolymerization. Existing research has shown strong mathematical correlations between the acceptor number (AN) and donor number (DN) with α, β, and π parameters, which helps quantify the impact of these parameters on the polarity of organic solvents [48,49]. To better understand the relationship between solvent parameters and yield, we established simulation equations (Eq. (2)) incorporating α, β, and π. The results indicate a high degree of correlation with an R² value of 0.984. The positive coefficients for α, β, and π suggest that these parameters play a supportive role in the liquid-phase depolymerization of CEL. Solvents with higher α, β, and π values are more favorable for CEL depolymerization. Additionally, a comparison of the coefficients reveals that the β coefficient is roughly half the size of α, indicating that while the solvent's hydrogen bond accepting ability contributes to the depolymerization process, its influence is weaker compared to hydrogen bond donating ability. The largest coefficient is associated with π, highlighting the critical importance of solvent polarity/polarizability in the depolymerization process. This effect holds even within the same solvent category, where solvents with higher π values are associated with higher yields of lignin-derived oily products. Additionally, the solvent donor number (DN) and acceptor number (AN) are key parameters that reflect the magnitudes of Lewis basicity and Lewis acidity, respectively, thus providing insights into the physicochemical properties of the solvent [48,49]. In Fig. 5(b), a clear linear correlation is observed between solvent DN and the yield of oily products, similar to the trend established with the solvent polarity parameter ET. However, dichloromethane shows a noticeable deviation from this linear relationship. By considering the solvent parameters of dichloromethane, as presented in Table 1, alongside Eq. (2), we suggest that its higher π value contributes positively to the reaction process, thereby enhancing the depolymerization yield. Based on this correlation, we propose a simulation equation (Eq. (3)) for DN, which yields an R² value of 0.913. The coefficients within this equation indicate the beneficial role of solvent Lewis basicity in CEL depolymerization and can be used to assess a solvent's potential for lignin conversion. Similarly, we developed a simulation equation (Eq. (4)) to describe the relationship between the acceptor number (AN) and lignin-derived oily products. The results reveal that, compared to the ET and DN models, the AN model shows larger deviations. By analyzing the coefficients in Eq. (2), it becomes clear that the sensitivity of solvent parameter α during the depolymerization process exceeds that of parameter β. In other words, the effect of AN, which is associated with α, outweighs the influence of DN, linked to β. This asymmetry results in more pronounced fluctuations in the AN fitting curve. In contrast, the DN model provides a better fit in experimental contexts when compared to the AN model. As a result, solvent donor number (DN) proves to be a more reliable parameter for predicting the yield of CEL liquid-phase depolymerization. However, within the factors influencing DN's effect on yield, the solvent's hydrogen bond donating capability plays a dominant role. Notably, the ET value itself is a composite outcome of both hydrogen bond donating and accepting capacities. Thus, the applicability of the ET model may extend beyond that of the DN model. Among the solvents tested, methanol demonstrated the highest effectiveness, yielding significant amounts of aromatic compounds. Key findings show that polarity was the most influential factor in the depolymerization process, followed by hydrogen bonding capabilities. Our simulations further highlighted that a comprehensive polarity parameter, incorporating both polarity and hydrogen bonding potential, best predicted the yield of oily products. These results emphasize the critical importance of solvent selection for optimizing lignin depolymerization, offering valuable insights for improving lignin valorization strategies and biorefinery processes. coredata.dc:description: The effects of solvents on lignin depolymerization are crucial for optimizing biomass valorization strategies. This study examines how various solvents influence oxidative lignin depolymerization under different reaction conditions. The findings highlight the significant role of solvents in lignin degradation, affecting conversion rates through factors like solvating capacity, polarity, and hydrogen bonding interactions. Notably, alcoholic solvents such as methanol exhibit strong catalytic effects due to their high polarity and hydrogen-donating capabilities. Under conditions with phosphomolybdic acid as the catalyst, methanol as the solvent, a temperature of 120 °C, a reaction time of 120 min, 1 MPa oxygen pressure, and a catalyst-to-lignin ratio of 1:1, the oxidative depolymerization of lignin yielded aromatic compounds with a production rate of 12.95 wt%. To further assess solvent effects, simulation models were developed, indicating that polarity has the most substantial impact, followed by hydrogen-bond donating and accepting properties. Particularly, a polarity parameter that comprehensively considers hydrogen bonding potential shows promise in predicting the yield of oily products during oxidative lignin depolymerization. These insights provide a foundation for selecting effective solvents to enhance lignin transformation, contributing to the development of sustainable biorefinery processes.
